description.narrative: Capacity building of Zimbabwe Statistical Agency and the National Statistics Systems
independent political entity
Number of poverty assessment surveys conducted Regular availability of statistical data/information through publication of statistical bulletins and reports including the PICES report.

comment.narrative: Weak National Development Statistical System No current national poverty data available need for coordination towards strengthening of ZIMSTAT through a system-wide appraoch.
1. Improved capacity and skills of ZIMSTAT staff 2. Improve physical, ICT and statistical infrastructure in ZIMSTAT and National Statistical System

1. The capacity needs assessment was started but not finalised. 2. The ICT needs assessment was conducted and completed and several other donors have used it to inform their support to ZIMSTAT’s ICT development.
1. Condust the Agricultural and Livestock survey and process all date 2. To Complete all backlog data process and publish all outstanding survey data
1. Data collection has been completed for the ALS 2. Backlog data processing is underway

description.narrative: 1. Draft National Gender Policy Implementation Strategy in place 2. Framework for GEPMI institutionalization at a public administration /academic 3. Gender Legal Framework in place 4. Extent to which the M&E capacities of the National Gender Machinery are strengthened 5. Framework for women's participation in place 6. Extent to which legislations are gender sensitive 7. Number of women benefiting from economic empowerment and support to livelihoods initiatives

comment.narrative: Draft National Gender Policy in Place but there is no implementation strategy 0 institutionalization of gender responsive budgeting and GEPMI Limited expertise in mainstreaming gender in economic policy planning

1. National Gender Policy launched 2. Draft Framework for institutionalization of GEPMI developed 3. Draft Gender Commission Institutional Framework developed 4. Draft Institutional Assessment Report produced 5. A draft framework for the participation of women in decision making developed 6. Draft lobbying and advocacy tools developed 7. Family Law Manual produced and published 8. One women's economic empowerment high impact project commissioned 9. Draft Framework for the establishment of a Women's Bank developed

1. New MoWAGCD Minister to present revised final National Gender Policy to Cabinet for approval. 2. Consultations between MoWAGCD and the Ministry of Higher and Tertiary Education are on-going. Planned activity with representatives from Academic Universities and Institutions to sensitize them on the GEPMI. 3. Procurement of 5 computers for the newly appointed Commissioners. 4. Consultant to carry the assessment of the Ministry of Women Affairs is on board and working on an inception report. 5 & 6. A workshop on economic and political empowerment for women was held in collaboration with the Parliament of Zimbabwe in June 2015. A second workshop on lobbying and advocacy for increased participation of women in politics and decision making is scheduled for 18-21 August with the Women's Parliamentary Caucus (including women directly representing political parties in Parliament). 7. A provincial validation workshop was conducted for provincial development officers, districts development officers, development officers and ward coordinators in Bulawayo in July 2015. 8. 39 women miners participated at the Mine Entra where they were exposed to mining technology, policies and regulations, mining financing amongst others. A Monitoring or field visit was carried out in Gwanda where the high impact project will be located, to assess the preparedness of the women miners association including environmental issues. One stampmill and two compressors have been procured. 9. A consultant was identified (KPMG International) and the MoWAGCD and MoFED are engaging the consultant to ascertain when the assigment can start (UNDP has released $60,000 to kickstart the process).

title.narrative: Scaling up adaptation with a f

description.narrative: Scaling up adaptation in Zimbabwe, with a focus on rural livelihoods
Social Protection, Land Housing and Community Amenities - disaster prevention and preparedness

Indicators as in AWP 2016
Output 1 Diversified and strengthened livelihoods and sources of income for vulnerable smallholder farmers in project area. Indicators: - Households and communities have more secure livelihood asset base (5 point rating) disaggregated by gender - Increase in agricultural and other sources of income - Number of financial transactions per Self Help Group increase - Volume of targeted locally produced commodities that are processed/value added and marketed by smallholder farmers increase
End of project targets: -Percentage of households with a rating of 4 on scale: Secure access to livelihood assets, increased by at least 20%. -50% of targeted smallholder farmers (by gender) have increased their agricultural income by at least 25%. -At least 50% of female headed households in each Self Help Group complete at least two financial transactions -At least 25% of targeted locally produced commodities in the three districts have value added and marketed by smallholder farmers
Output 2: Increased knowledge and understanding of climate variability and change-induced risks in targeted vulnerable areas Indicators: - Relevant climate risk information disseminated to stakeholders - Climate information routinely and effectively used in making climate sensitive decisions
End of project targets: -70% of smallholder farmers in the project area have access to localised climate forecasts - Climate information being routinely and effectively used by at least 50% of smallholder farmers (by gender) to make climate sensitive decisions.
Output 3: Monitoring, learning, adaptive feedback and evaluation Indicators: - Effective selection and implementation of adaptation measures
Output 4: Project management Indicators: - Delivery rate

comment.narrative:
Baseline data as described in AWP 2016
Output 1 Diversified and strengthened livelihoods and sources of income for vulnerable smallholder farmers in project area. Baseline: - Households in project area have poor access (rating 2) to livelihood assets - Baseline agricultural income per household. Buhera $444/year, Chimanimani $864/year and Chiredzi $456 /year. - Number of existing financial self help groups and baseline financial transactions. Buhera 18,3%, Chimanimani 26,7% and Chiredzi 15,1%. - Three (3) short value chains to be targeted (Buhera: Goat, cattle, sorghum, honey. Chimanimani: Potato, goats, honey, beans, pepper and Chiredzi: Sorghum, pearl millet, cattle and goats). The baseline volume of products marketed to be determined.
Output 2: Increased knowledge and understanding of climate variability and change-induced risks in targeted vulnerable areas Baseline - Smallholder farmers in target districts do not have access to regular localised climate forecasts and protocols for effective use in risk management (Buhera 71,7%, Chimanimani 76,4% and Chiredzi 65,3%) - Climate information not routinely used by stakeholders in the targeted districts
Output 3: Monitoring, learning, adaptive feedback and evaluation Baseline: - Adaptation measures that work well in the targeted areas not clearly established
Output 4: Project management

Output 1 Diversified and strengthened livelihoods and sources of income for vulnerable smallholder farmers in project area. Targets: - 4,400 households, being 800 households in Buhera, 1800 (Chimanimani) and 1800 (Chiredzi) increasing livelihood asset base from the implemented strategic integrated micro-watershed CCA investments implemented. - 800 female headed households in each targeted micro-watershed have improved access to financial services and financial transactions per Self Help Group increase by 25% over the baseline - 200 households in each of the three targeted value chains have improved market literacy and linkages with markets and service providers, and their volume of marketed products increase by 20% over the baseline. - Agricultural and income from other sources among at least 25% of the farmers participating in the project increase by at least 20% over the baseline.
Output 2: Increased knowledge and understanding of climate variability and change-induced risks in targeted vulnerable areas Targets: - 4,400 households being 800 households in Buhera, 1800 in Chimanimani and 1800 in Chiredzi receiving relevant climate risk information. - 25% of targeted farmers routinely and effectively using climate information to make climate sensitive decisions. - Stakeholders have capacity to reach at least 25% of targeted beneficiaries with improved climate services for climate risk management
Output 3: Monitoring, learning, adaptive feedback and evaluation Targets: - Monitoring results supporting the long term process of learning (what works) and adjustments of adaptation choices to enhance project impact - Project communication influencing other projects, geographical areas, policy makers and wider public to promote scaling up
Output 4: Project management Targets: - 100% delivery - Project managed effectively - Project is visible at local, national and international levels

Output 1 Diversified and strengthened livelihoods and sources of income for vulnerable smallholder farmers in project area. Target: 4,400 households (70% being women) across the three districts increasing livelihood asset base from at least three strategic adaptation investments implemented. Progress: A total of 713 households across the three districts being, 239 male and 212 female headed households in Buhera District, 154 male, 37 female headed households in Chimanimani District, and 31 male, 40 female headed households in Chiredzi District benefited from livelihood asset base improving adaptation investments. Partially reached: (16% of target in terms of number of households, 40,5% of these were female headed households).
In addition 1750 and 204 households in Buhera and Chiredzi District respectively had improved access to water for domestic and productive purposes.6300 farmers from the baseline Food Security project in Chiredzi District received Climate Change awareness.
Target:800 female headed households in each targeted micro-watershed have improved access to financial services and financial transactions per Self Help Group increase by 25% over the baseline. Progress: 311 women and 97 men in Chiredzi District have improved access to financial services and are involved in borrowing and lending for productive purposes. Partially reached (17% of target). No account of # or increase in % of financial transactions.
Target: 200 households in each of the three targeted value chains have improved market literacy and linkages with markets and service providers, and their volume of marketed products increase by 20% over the baseline. Progress: Market literacy and volume of marketed honey increased for 30 farmers from Buhera District. Priority value chains across the three districts have just been identified and producer groups have just been formed. Partially reached (15% of target # of farmers).
Target: Agricultural and income from other sources among at l

Output 1 Diversified and strengthened livelihoods and sources of income for vulnerable smallholder farmers in project area. Targets: - Cumulatively 9,800 households, being 2000 households in Buhera, 3500 (Chimanimani) and 4300 (Chiredzi) increasing livelihood asset base from the implemented strategic integrated micro-watershed CCA investments implemented. - Cumulatively 1800 female headed households in each targeted micro-watershed have improved access to financial services and financial transactions per Self Help Group increase by 25% over the baseline - Cumulatively 600 households in each of the three targeted value chains have improved market literacy and linkages with markets and service providers, and their volume of marketed products increase by 20% over the baseline. - Agricultural and income from other sources among at least 25% of the farmers participating in the project increase by at least 20% over the baseline.
Output 2: Increased knowledge and understanding of climate variability and change-induced risks in targeted vulnerable areas Targets: - (4,400 households) being 800 households in Buhera, 1800 in Chimanimani and 1800 in Chiredzi receiving relevant climate risk information. - 25% of targeted farmers routinely and effectively using climate information to make climate sensitive decisions. - Stakeholders have capacity to reach at least 25% of targeted beneficiaries with improved climate services for climate risk management
Output 3: Monitoring, learning, adaptive feedback and evaluation Targets: - Monitoring results supporting the longterm process of learning (what works) and adjustments of adaptation choices to enhance project impact - Project communication influencing other projects, geographical areas, policy makers and wider public to promote scaling up
Output 4: Project management Targets: - 100% delivery - Project managed effectively - Project is visible at local, national and international levels

Output1:Diversified and strengthened livelihoods and sources of income for vulnerable smallholder farmers in project area. End of project target: (Cumulatively 9,800 households) being 2,000 households in Buhera, 3,500 (Chimanimani) and 4,300 (Chiredzi) increasing livelihood asset base from the implemented strategic integrated micro-watershed CCA investments implemented Progress: Cumulatively 3,941 households (2006 males, 1935 females) being 1248 households (649 males,599 females) in Buhera, 1648 households(930 males, 718 females) in Chimanimani and 1045 households (427 males, 618 females) in Chiredzi) have improved access to livelihood asset to build resilience to impacts of climate shocks through investments in water, climate smart agriculture, DRR training and natural ecosystem managements. Access to water has reached 3,069 households across the three districts and 7,273 people were reached through awareness campaigns on climate change and watershed management.
Target: Cumulatively 1800 female headed households in each targeted micro-watershed have improved access to financial services and financial transactions per Self Help Group increase by 25% over the baseline Progress: Trainings in financial literacy resulted in 303 households (11 males, 292 females) in Buhera, 249 households (72males, 177 females) in Chimanimani and 898 households (238males, 660 females) having improved access to financial services through formation of Village Savings and Lending Associations (VSLAs) – in total 1450 households trained in 2016. A cumulative total of 102 VSLA groups were established and remain functional (57 Chiredzi, 22 Chimanimani and 23 Buhera). In Chiredzi District, 25 groups had saved a total of US$36,442.73, in Buhera 16 groups saved US$11,640 and in Chimanimani 14 groups saved US$2,392 by end of December 2016. Some of the groups shared out their saved funds at the end of December 2016. In Chiredzi 9 groups shared out $18,600, in Buhera 3 groups shared out $6,

Output targets 2017: Outputs 1.1: Three strategic adaptation Investments developed and implemented in each of the targeted microwatershed of Odzi, Save, Nuanetsi/Runde in Chimanimani, Buhera and Chiredzi Districts Cumulative target: 2000 households reached through adaptive investments in Buhera. 3750 households reached though adaptive investments in Chimanimani. 4350 households reached though adaptive investments in Chiredzi. (10100 in total)
Output 1.2. Inclusive Financial services established to support climate risk management to benefit at least 3000 women Cumulative target: 1800 households reached through village savings and lending
Output 1.3. Market linkages for 3000 households and 3 short value chains established. Cumulative target: 1000 households linked to markets. Honey, cattle, goats, sorghum value chain promoted in Buhera. Beans value chain promoted in Chimanimani. Sorghum, beef, honey, beans value chains promoted in Chiredzi.
Output 2.1 One district and three (3) WARD level Climate User- Interface Platforms for agriculture and DRM established and operational. Target: Operationalisation of the CUIP through dissemination of weather and climate information using the SMS system
Output 2.2 Capacity of service providers and users to enable all activities of the Framework for Climate Services to occur, be scaled up and to have climate services reach at least 70% of targeted beneficiaries developed. Target: MSD supported to produce weekly products, monitor observation equipment,
Output 3.1. M&E plan established. Target: Profile all the reached beneficiaries (10100 households)
Output 3.2Knowledge Management and communication platform to support Learning, project visibility and facilitate replication established Target: Produce 2 newsletters, MSC stories, indepth analysis of adaptive investments

All (100%) of the internal audit recommendation have been acted upon within the agreed time 3. 100% of the lab machines and chemistry analysers have been serviced and are functional by service provider. description.narrative: Increased capacities of communities to protect development gains and achieve improved well-being outcomes in the face of shocks and stresses enabling them to contribute to the economic growth of Zimbabwe
Social Protection, Land Housing and Community Amenities - disaster prevention and preparedness

OUTPUT 1: Application of evidence in policy making for resilience increased. # of national and sub-national assessments that inform development planning and programming, taking into account differentiated impacts on women and men # of knowledge products at national and subnational levels that inform resilience planning and programming # of community projects that utilize evidence for improved resilience.

OUTPUT 1: Effective evidence based institutional, legislative and policy frameworks in place at national and sub-national levels for increased resilience-
-M&E system developed
-Consensus around Theory of Change built
OUTPUT 2: Absorptive, Adaptive and Transformative capacities of at-risk communities increased and improved via ZRBF investments.
- ZRBF management unit fully functioning - Funding modalities designed - ToRs for Steering Committee Developed - Office spaces identified and organized - First RfP developed
OUTPUT 3: Timely and cost effective response to emergencies rolled out via existing safety net and other relevant programmes.
- Mechanisms developed to identify triggers and improve preparedness -Response mechanisms identified

OUTPUT 1: Application of evidence in policy making for resilience increased.
-A National multi hazard index was developed to the lowest administrative level (ward level) accompanied by hazard specific and combined maps. The methodology and products were endorsed by a multi stakeholder workshop in September 2015. A publication is currently under development.
-The development of the M&E system was postponed and is expected to be finalized by mid 2016
- Consensus has been build between Government, UN, Civil Society and Academia around a Strategic Framework for Resilience in Zimbabwe. Consultations to build consensus around the Theory of Change for ZRBF have been on-going since August 2015 and reached between UN and Government. The multi stakeholder consultation will be finalized in January 2016
OUTPUT 2: Absorptive, Adaptive and Transformative capacities of at-risk communities increased and improved via ZRBF investments.
- The ZRBF management unit has undertaken recruitment of 4 out of 10 project staff members and is partially functioning. Office spaces have been identified and organized. Procurement processes are on-going for refurbishment and vehicles.
Funding modalities under ZRBF has been proposed to an accepted by funding donors and a procurement strategy developed. The ToRs for the project steering committee have been developed. A EoI was conducted as part of the funding modality and a RfP is expected to be released end of January 2016
OUTPUT 3: Timely and cost effective response to emergencies rolled out via existing safety net and other relevant programmes.
The development of the crisis modifier has been postponed to first quarter of 2016

OUTPUT 1: Application of evidence in policy making for resilience increased.
-National risk and hazard profile for resilience building endorsed
-M&E system developed
-Consensus around Theory of Change built
OUTPUT 2: Absorptive, Adaptive and Transformative capacities of at-risk communities increased and improved via ZRBF investments.
- ZRBF management unit fully functioning - Funding modalities designed - ToRs for Steering Committee Developed - Office spaces identified and organized - First CfP developed
OUTPUT 3: Timely and cost effective response to emergencies rolled out via existing safety net and other relevant programmes.
- Mechanisms developed to identify triggers and improve preparedness -Response mechanisms identified

OUTPUT 1: Application of evidence in policy making for resilience increased. -National risk and hazard profile for resilience building endorsed  A National multi hazard index was developed to the lowest administrative level (ward level) accompanied by hazard specific and combined maps. The products were endorsed by a multi stakeholder workshop in September 2015. However, the publication was completed and disseminated to a wider audience during the reporting period. Moreover, a total of 36 multi hazard maps produced to date to inform resilience planning and programming.
-M&E system developed  During the second quarter of 2016, Zimbabwe resilience building fund Monitoring, Evaluation & Learning Strategic Framework, including Log frame was developed and circulated for comments to the development partners. Following constructive feedback, the Monitoring, Evaluation and Learning (MEAL) framework was developed & presented during the August 2016 Steering Committee meeting and shared for review and sign off. Furthermore, ZRBF’s overall log frame has been developed and signed off on 14th September, 2016.
-Consensus around Theory of Change built  The TOC were validated and endorsed by a multi stakeholder workshop in January 2016. TOC development: the problem tree analysis, and a study on risks and vulnerabilities in the cross field between Gender, Climate Change and Livelihood was undertaken to feed into the development of the Theory of Change for ZRBF. The study contributed significantly to the development of the Theory of Change
- Application of evidence in planning for resilience work in Zimbabwe  One key point identified in the Zimbabwe resilience strategic framework was the need for evidence to determine contributing factors, the context, types of hazards and relationships between the hazards and wellbeing outcomes. The ZRBF analytical products were developed to fulfil this need as well inform the ZRBF Theory of Change. The key products were Hazards Mapping, Cor

comment.narrative: Preparations are underway for a baseline assessment covering the four target districts of Lupane, Binga, Nkayia nd Gokwe S.

1.1: 1.1.1: Four (4) Baselines assessments (1 for each district) 1.1.2: Fully functional district office in Nkayi 1.2.2: Cooperative training manual produced 1.2.3: 20 officers trained in SIYB 1.2.4: 25 officers trained in Cooperative Management 1.3.1 & 2: 5 fully functional Livelihoods Committees (1 national, and 1 for each district) 1.3.4: 5000 copes of the Finance brochure & 3000 copies of the MSME magazine produced and disseminated
2.1: 2.1.1: 60 SACCO members allocated seed funds 2.1.2: 300 beneficiary (representing SMEs) exposed to potential financiers through the MSME Finance Expo 2.3.1: $30,000 worth of value added products sent to market 2.4.1: 5 youth starts ups (as a result of the provision of start- up kits) 2.4.2: Fully functional Common Facility centres in Lupane and Nkayi 2.4.3: 100 young farmers trained in business development 2.4.4: Mobile innovation lab rolled out to sub-national level 2.4.5: 3 Innovation4Agric solutions piloted and tested

The multi-year work plan in the project RRF dedicated year 1 to preparatory work. Thus, most of the first 2 quarters have been spent on project set up including recruitment. Some results were achieved as follows:
2.1 - 170 (102 female, 68 male) SACCO members trained in the effective administration of Savings and Credit Cooperatives 2.2 - 45 (35 women, 10 male) community molibisers trained (ToT for SACCOs) 2.3 - 166 (72 female, 44 male) people trained in business management 2.4: Electrification and set up Nkayi common facility centre for use in micro business support and training

title.narrative: Enhanced Climate Action for Low Carbon & Climate Resilie

description.narrative: The IRRF is UNDP’s results framework to monitor and report on its achievements against the Strategic Plan 2014-2017. UNDP publishes country level IRRF results that UNDP’s projects contributed to
Number of preparedness plans that cover only response
Number of preparedness plans that cover response AND recovery
The focus of the intervention is on scaled up climate change mitigation and adaptation and strengthened resilience capacities to cope with natural and man-made shocks and stresses.
Social Protection, Land Housing and Community Amenities - disaster prevention and preparedness

Output 1. Scaled up action on climate change adaptation and mitigation in vulnerable districts is funded and implemented Output 1: End of project target: Indicator 1.1. 5000 households ( Aggregated by Male and Female-led) using climate-smart agriculture production technologies and sustainable energy practices under SE4All initiative Indicator 1.2. A total of 15 community groups developing gender sensitive adaptation strategies and measures for climate resilience in 5 districts Indicator 1.3. 1 gender sensitive national adaptation plan and 5 district development plans that address biodiversity and ecosystem management and climate risk management
Output 2: Mechanisms in place to assess and mitigate natural and man-made risks at the subnational level Mid term and end of project target: Indicator 2. 1. By 2020, 5 gender sensitive district development plans that address disaster and risk management have been adopted Indicator 2.2: By December 2017, 3 multi-hazard mappings at subnational levels have been carried out and inform planning and programming, taking into account differentiated impact on women and men.

comment.narrative:
Output 1. Scaled up action on climate change adaptation and mitigation in vulnerable districts is funded and implemented Baseline: to be determined by baseline studies
Output 2: Mechanisms in place to assess and mitigate natural and man-made risks at the subnational level Baseline: 2.1. to be determined by baseline studies 2.2. Nil

Output 1: Scaled up action on climate change adaptation and mitigation in vulnerable districts is funded and implemented i. Five potential adaptation and mitigation rural projects identified in vulnerable districts ii. Detailed assesments conducted on each project iii. Progress towards NAP iv. Progress towards Low Carbon Development Strategy v. Progress towards district level gender and climate sensitive DRM plans vi. Renewable Energy Policy finalized vii. Forestry Policy finalized viii. Two project ideas developed into concept note/proposal ix. MEA Reports for SE4ALL and UNFCCC meetings
Output 2: Mechanisms in place to assess and mitigate natural and man-made risks at the subnational level i. Meteorological equipment needs identified and costed for set up in high climate disaster risk areas ii. Climate disaster database needs list iii. Global DRM event Reports iv. Floodplain Management Framework
Output 3: Project effectively planned, implemented and monitored i. Project coordination and management mechanism in place. MOUs with IP and RPs; Coordinator; Assistant; ii. AWP, 4 costed QWP, 4 Quarterly reports and budgets. iii. Two project ideas and Pipeline projects developed to mobilise

Output 1: Scaled up action on climate change adaptation and mitigation in vulnerable districts is funded and implemented At the sub-national level, the project was introduced to all the five districts in which community level adaptation and mitigation interventions are to be implemented. Furthermore one technical partner and two CSOs operating in two of the districts (Buhera and Chiredzi) were identified as local level implementing partners whose ongoing project activities in the GEF/UNDP Scaling Up Adaptation project can be enhanced through the SECA Project. UNV project officers were recruited during the course of the year and commenced work in the last quarter of the year in Bulilima, Lupane and Gokwe South. Baseline study is ongoing in Gokwe South, Lupane and Bulilima. The development of district and ward level gender and climate sensitive DRM Plans moved to 2017. During the year, the project provided significant support to the crafting of the Renewable Energy Policy and the National Forest Policy through funding some of the main consultative workshops and by providing technical support on climate change. The Renewable Energy Policy now awaits a final stakeholder endorsement meeting to be conducted in February 2017 whilst the National Forest Policy has been validated and is being finalized before being presented to other arms of government for scrutiny. The project funded capacity development for private sector engagement in the Clean Development Mechanism and low carbon development strategy in line with the objectives of the country’s Nationally Determined Contributions to the UNFCCC. A number of companies have embarked on CDM project development. The process for developing a Low Carbon Development Strategy has not advanced significantly. The project provided support for capacity building on Green Climate Fund proposal development for two Ministry of Environment, Water and Climate officers. In collaboration among MEWC/UNDP/Climate Resilient Infrastructure Dev

Output 1: Scaled up action on climate change adaptation and mitigation in vulnerable districts is funded and implemented i. National Adaptation Plan finalised ii. 2016 HDR finalised and launched iii. RE policy finalised. iv. More efficient EIS with mapping capabilities v. Schools RE resources book finalised vi. Climate and energy information disseminated vii. GCF proposal finalised. Mitigation concept note developed viii. Recommendations on planning, policy and strategy provided with a basis in participation in UNFCCC and relevant energy/mitigation fora.
Output 2: Mechanisms in place to assess and mitigate natural and man-made risks at the subnational level i. Indicators for SFDRR developed ii. Climate resilient infrastructure guide for schools developed iii. Updated DRM plans for Bulilima, Gokwe South, Lupane iv. Recommendations provided for DRM in policy, planning and programming.
Output 3: Project effectively planned, implemented and monitored i. Baseline study document finalised and recommendations feeding into design of project interventions ii. AWP, 4 costed QWP, 4 Quarterly reports and budgets.

To enhance national and community dispute resolution capacities, providing dialogue platforms for consensus and confidence building, while fostering tolerance, encouraging inclusiveness and collaboration in the delivery of development dividends.
Social Protection, Land Housing and Community Amenities - disaster prevention and preparedness

1. Number of coordinated Peacebuilding Partners’ meetings/events convened on a quarterly basis 2. a. NPRC and its Secretariat are equipped to effectively execute its Constitutional mandate 2. b. National Framework and Implementation Plan for Reconciliation in place 2.c. Number of NPRC internal organizational tools developed 2.d. Database of actioned early warning signals 3.a. High level platforms enabling confidence building processes through dialogue 4.a. No. of LPCs providing dispute resolution and mediation services [disaggregated by No. of LPCs in place, Peace mediators (PM), No. of Peace dividend initiatives] 4.b.A Dispute Management System for Local Peace Committees with at least 200 cases successfully resolved and documented is in place

comment.narrative: 1.a. There is currently no joint inter ministerial entity working on peace and social cohesion 2.a.The NPRC was established by the 2013 Constitution, Commissioners were sworn in on 24th February 2016 2.b. There is no national framework and implementation plan for reconciliation 2.c There is no NPRC internal organizational tools in place to guide the NPRC’s work 2.d A draft framework for the establishment of the CEWER has been designed 3. 0 4.a. 188 (LPCs); 179 (PM); 4 (Peace Dividends) 4.b. Absence of a dispute management system to track the number of cases resolved

1. A Government Working Group on Peace and Social Cohesion is established 2. a. NPRC and its Secretariat is in place 2.b. A draft Internal Reconciliation and Peacebuilding Strategy is designed ; At least 1 national awareness & consensus building session convened 2.c. At least 2 drafts are developed 2. d. A working group is established to design the CEWER mechanism; 3. DRG with 20 Members in place; At least 4 high level platforms for stakeholder dialogue established 4.a 50 LPCs (in 2 selected districts); 50 PM; 20 Peace dividend Programmes 4.b A dispute management system is set up with 50 cases documented

1. For 2016, and as informed by the withdrawal of the NPRC Bill from Parliament, the focus for the OPC has been on facilitating multi-stakeholder input into the draft NPRC Bill. 2.a An Induction and Orientation Programme was delivered for the sworn-in NPRC Commissioners to equip them with skills and competencies in preparation for carrying out their mandate. As part of the roll out of the plan, the Capacity Enhancement Retreats contributed to laying the foundations for confidence, cohesion and trust building within the Commission, as well as sensitization to key concepts and enablers of facilitating peace and reconciliation. 2.b & c The 9 Commissioners were sworn in in February 2016, however the enabling legislation is not yet in place. Finalization of the NPRC Act is expected for 2017. 2.d Three initial consultative meetings have been held within Civil Society Organizations leading to the identification of three capacity development needs around: a) development of an Indicator Databank / Dashboard for effective data collection; b)Capacities for data collection, verification, validation, analyzing and reporting for response. (Tools & Methodologies and Incentives); Capacities for mobilizing multiple stakeholder responses through constructive and sustained engagement strategies. Further efforts will resume in 2017. 3. A multi-sectoral dialogue space entitled “The Champions Dialogue Group” or Dialogue Reference Group (composed of 15 selected leaders) initiated in April 2016, has since met four times leading to the definition of shared and common identify, the identification of common issues of interests and the mapping of capacity needs. In addition, three other high level dialogue platforms were supported in 2016 including the Creative Arts and Culture Leaders Forum (initiated in September 2016), the Zimbabwe Heads of Christian Denominations (ZHOCD) in spearheading dialogue and reconciliation efforts, and the CSOs dialogue platform on EWER. 4. a. 36 LPCs have dem

1. Four (4) meetings/events to be convened in 2017 by the GoZ through the OPC (at least one per quarter) 2.a NPRC Commissioners equipped with relevant skills 2.b Draft National Framework and Implementation Plan for Reconciliation in place (informed by the NPRC Bill) 2.c Three (3): a Gender Policy, an Internal Communication Policy, Information Management System are in place 3.a. At least 4 national and 20 community level consensus building sessions held through dialogue platforms 3.b At least two national and 5 community level consensus building sessions targeting women 4.a 26 LPCs; 30 PM ; 4 peace dividend initiatives 4.b A dispute management system is updated with 150 cases

description.narrative: The primary objective of the Programme is to support the local government reforms, strengthen the capacities of the sub national governance architecture, and contribute to poverty eradication and realization of the SDGS.
Project seeks to; “Enhance Sustainable and Inclusive Service Delivery by Local Government”.
Environment - policy, planning and administration

Result Indicator 1.1 The Local Authorities Bills presented to Parliament. Result Indicator 1.2 The National Local Government Policy adopted and popularised. Result Indicator 1.3 he SLB Framework rolled out in all the local authorities. Result Indicator 1.4 Service Delivery Monitoring and Evaluation Framework rolled out in all the local authorities. Result Indicator 1.5 SDGs Localisation Framework rolled out in all the Local Authorities.
Result Indicator 2.1 Enhanced capacities in the local government sector Result Indicator 2.2 Improved the business process and enhanced easy of doing business at the local government level Result Indicator 2.3 Result Indicator 2.4 Result Indicator 2.5 Result Indicator 3.1 Result Indicator 3.2
Result Indicator 4.1 Result Indicator 4.2 Result Indicator 4.3 Result Indicator 4.4
Result Indicator 5.1 Result Indicator 5.2 Result Indicator 5.3

comment.narrative:
Result Indicator 1.1. Baseline (2016): There is no local government legislation aligned to the constitution. There are 30 pieces of legislation that need to be aligned. Result Indicator 1.2. There is no national Local Government Policy. Result Indicator 1.3 WASH sector service level benchmark for urban local authorities is in place. Result Indicator 1.4 There is no service delivery monitoring and evaluation framework. Result Indicator 1.5 There is no SDGs Localisation Framework.
Result Indicator 2.1. Capacity Assessment Report 2013 Result Indicator 2.2 Weak business processes and challenging easy of doing business context in the local government sector Result Indicator 2.3 There are limited LED interventions in local government Result Indicator 2.4 average 40% revenue collection efficiency Result Indicator 2.5 Few Initiatives on Alternative Service Delivery Models (TBA on specificities)
Result Indicator 3.1 No citizen participation and engagement policy Result Indicator 3.2 The capacity of the sub-national participatory planning structures is reported to be weak (TBA after the assessment)
Result Indicator 4.1 Limited organisational learning happening. Result Indicator 4.2 Limited use of ICT Result Indicator 4.3 TBA
Result Indicator 5.1 No gender responsive Local Government policy Result Indicator 5.2 There are no gender sensitive service delivery indicators Result Indicator 5.3 TBA

Result Indicator 1.1 The Local Authorities Bills presented to Parliament. Result Indicator 1.2 National Local Government Policy drafted. Result Indicator 1.3 Data to develop the SLB Framework gathered. Result Indicator 1.4 Monitoring and Evaluation Framework piloted in 30% of the local Authorities. Result Indicator 1.5 Draft SGDs localisation Framework.
Result Indicator 2.1 Rapid capacity assessment of the selected local authorities and capacity development plans per local authority Result Indicator 2.2 Business processes in local authorities assessed and intervention plans developed. Result Indicator 2.3 Local Economic Development Opportunities and challenges per Local Authorities identifies and LED strategies developed Result Indicator 2.4 an assessment report of the factors impeding revenue collection and generation. Result Indicator 2.5 A study into the state of play in terms of Service Delivery Models
Result Indicator 3.1 Draft citizen participation and engagement policy. Result Indicator 3.2 The capacity of the sub-national participatory planning structures developed (TBA after the assessment)
Result Indicator 4.1 Organisational learning system installed and functional in the selected local authorities Result Indicator 4.2 All Local Authorities with functional ICT and connectivity Result Indicator 4.3 Assessment of the capacities of the knowledge institutions to support the local government sector and development of intervention plans
Result Indicator 5.1 Gender marker for the ministries.

1.1 National consultations on the Traditional Leaders Bill (5 provinces) was conducted and the drafting process of the Bill has commenced. The Local Authorities Bills is still under review before it's presented to Parliament. 1.2 Drafting of the Rural Development Strategy is in place and awaits validation. 1.3 Draft SLB Framework developed for various service lines (roads, social amenities, governance, planning and settlements, street lighting) to be adopted by Local Authorities. 1.4 Draft M&E framework in the final stages and M&E training for M&E Officers in the two ministries conducted.
2.1 Assess the capacity of 10 Local authorities (5rural and 5 urban) to done in Q4. 2.2 The Orientation and Induction of new personnel in the two Ministries on the business processes was done at the Highlands Training Centre. 2.3 The Local Economic Development Opportunities and challenges per Local Authorities identifies and LED strategies is still pending. 2.4 An assessment report of the factors impeding revenue collection and generation is still pending.
3.1 Draft citizen participation and engagement policy is pending in Q4. 3.2 Development of “Me and My Council” handbook developed to inform the public and guide local authorities on their mandates.
4.1 The identification of the learning needs of the personnel in the two Ministries is still pending. 4.2 All Local Authorities with functional ICT and connectivity is still pending. 4.3 Engagement of Midlands State of University (MSU) on Local Economic Development conducted and a Post-Graduate Diploma course outline was jointly developed by MSU.
5.1 A Gender Marker Training was held for the Gender Focal Persons in the two local government ministries and ToRs for the focal persons are being drafted.

1. Capacity Assessments (including revenue generation, collection efficiency and local economic development) of at least six selected local authorities undertaken. 2. Service Level Benchmarking (Baselines, Performance Improvement Plans, and M&E Plans) of at least two selected local authorities’ setup. 3. Draft National Rural Development Strategy developed. 4. Regional, Country and Planning Act reviewed and draft amendments developed. 5. Finalise the draft citizen participation and engagement framework. 6. Draft Gender Responsive Local Government Policy developed. 7. Establish Gender Sensitive Service Delivery Indicators Framework.

The National Rural Development Strategy (NRDS) formulation Internal Consultative in the Ministry of Rural Development, Promotion and Preservation of National Culture and Heritage conducted 7-10 March, 2017.

description.narrative: Aid Coordination

participating-org.narrative: Min. of Fin. and Economic Dev.

description.narrative: The IRRF is UNDP’s results framework to monitor and report on its achievements against the Strategic Plan 2014-2017. UNDP publishes country level IRRF results that UNDP’s projects contributed to
number of additional females benefitting from UNDP's livelihoods interventions
number of additional males benefitting from UNDP's livelihoods interventions
number of additional people benefitting from UNDP's livelihoods interventions
aid coordination
policy, planning and administration
